bioghist.p: Edwin Ewart Aubrey (1896-1956) was born in Glasgow, Scotland, and became a naturalized citizen of the United States in 1918. He earned his Bachelor of Philosophy degree from Bucknell University in 1919. His Master of Arts (1921), Bachelor of Divinity (1922), and Doctor of Philosophy (1926) were all received from the University of Chicago. Aubrey taught at Carleton College, Miami University (Ohio), Vassar College, and the University of Chicago, before becoming the president of Crozer Theological Seminary, Chester, Pennsylvania, in 1944. He remained at Crozer until 1949, when he established the Department of Religious Thought at the University of Pennsylvania. Simon Patrick (1626-1707), English divine, was dean of Peterborough in 1679, and Bishop of Chichester in 1689, in which year he was employed, along with others of the new bishops, to settle the affairs of the Church in Ireland. In 1691 he was translated to the see of Ely, which he held until his death on the 31st of May 1707. His numerous sermons and devotional writings were highly regarded and influential.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes a typescript project proposal for a Fulbright scholarship (Aubrey died before the proposal came up for consideration). The proposal is titled "The Theology of Simon Patrick (1626-1707)" and includes a bibliography of Patrick's works and chronology of his life. There are also typed and manuscript bibliographic and reading notes and extracts. Some of the notes are arranged chronologically (by period of Patrick's life). There are also reader request slips from Princeton, the Huntington Library, and the University of Pennsylvania.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
